Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSE: PERTURBO: A Software for Accelerated Discovery of Microscopic Electronic Processes in Materials

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The electronic, optical, and thermal properties of materials are determined by microscopic electron collisions that take place inside materials on a time scale of a trillionth of a second (a picosecond), and are thus very hard to study experimentally. This project supports the development of a computer program, called PERTURBO, which will be used to study the dynamics of electrons in materials, with a view to understanding electron collisions. The only input needed by PERTURBO to solve the equations of quantum mechanics that control electron motion is the atomic structure of the material under study. In addition, PETURBO use innovative computational techniques to solve these equations efficiently. Thus PERTURBO may be used not just to study existing materials but also to study the next generation of more complex materials and devices. The application of PERTURBO to materials will enable disruptive advances in electronics, lighting, energy, and other technologies. Further, experimental facilities of national interest, such as the free-electron laser and other ambitious experiments to understand materials on a fundamental level, are in critical need of theoretical and computational tools to understand electron dynamics at microscopic levels. PERTURBO fills an important gap in the scientific software needed for the future development of science and technology in the United States, thus serving NSF's science mission, and places the country at the leading edge of materials and device research. Finally, the code will be freely available, user-friendly, and widely usable; users will include academic research groups, national laboratories, and industry.

This award supports the development of PERTURBO, a robust software platform to compute from first principles the scattering processes among electrons, phonons, defects, photons, and excitons in materials. The modular architecture of PERTURBO revolves around fast parallel routines to compute electron-phonon, electron-electron, electron-defect, and electron-photon scattering processes. The code employs novel techniques to compute and interpolate the matrix elements and converge the timescale for these scattering processes. PERTURBO imports inputs from density functional theory, density functional perturbation theory, and GW-BSE calculations, and is interfaced with routines to compute and output transport properties and ultrafast electron dynamics. For enhanced usability, a Python driver will be developed to automatically run the calculations and analyze the results. PERTURBO allows the users to quantitatively study charge, heat, and energy transport in novel materials, including semiconductors, insulators, metals, nanostructures, and interfaces, as well as ultrafast electron and excited state dynamics. The code fills​ a major void in the current software ecosystem. In particular, it addresses the need to more deeply understand electron dynamics in the post-Moore's law era of electronics, as well as study ultrafast electronic processes of key importance for advanced ultrafast time-resolved spectroscopies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The interactions between electrons and atomic vibrations (phonons) control a wide range of properties in materials, including their electrical transport, optical response and superconductivity. The PI develops quantum mechanical calculations that can accurately predict the microscopic motion of electrons in materials, providing an insight, resolution, and quantitative detail beyond the reach of experiments. These calculations are called "first-principles" (or ab initio) because they take as input only the atomic structure of the material and, without using empirical parameters or experimental inputs, aim to make quantitative predictions of materials properties.

This program supported the development of PERTURBO, an open-source code to investigate electron-phonon (e-ph) interactions, charge transport and ultrafast non-equilibrium dynamics in materials using first-principles calculations. At present, PERTURBO is the only existing code able to accurately compute e-ph interactions and the resulting electron dynamics in various families of complex materials, including those with spin-orbit coupling, polar bonds, piezoelectricity and soft phonons. Calculations are possible for materials with a noteworthy structural complexity, with up to 50-100 atoms in the unit cell. PERTURBO can also model the ultrafast electron dynamics in materials excited by short light pulses, and characterize it down to the femtosecond time scale characteristic of non-equilibrium electron motion. 

PERTURBO was developed following modern standards of software engineering - it is modular, user friendly, and efficient - and it has been parallelized to run on systems ranging from small computer clusters to petascale supercomputers. Performance tests show that the PERTURBO code scales favorably up to thousands of CPU cores by leveraging its hybrid MPI plus OpenMP parallelization. PERTURBO has been praised by the community, amassing over 200 users in less than a year of its release. This new computational tool is rapidly forming a broad new community of scientists pursuing studies of e-ph interactions and electron dynamics from first principles. The PI and his team held two workshops in year 2020, which have trained over 200 participants in total; one workshop trained users in the US and one users in Europe and Asia. Several undergraduate interns have contributed to the code development. 

The scientific accomplishments of the project included uniquely novel calculations of e-ph interactions, charge transport and ultrafast dynamics, as well as accurate calculations of light emission, radiative lifetimes, exciton dynamics and light-matter interaction. The three-year project resulted in 15 publications cited already over 250 times. Specific examples include calculations of electrical transport in semiconductors and oxides that achieve remarkable agreement with experiments and shed light on the microscopic mechanisms governing transport, such as which phonon modes scatter the carriers more strongly, or the microscopic origin of the temperature dependence of the mobility. For example, work supported by this program explained the microscopic origin of charge transport in a technologically important transition metal oxide, SrTiO3 perovskite, in which we discovered that electrons interact strongly with soft and polar phonons and break the conventional scattering regime and its associated Planckian limit at room temperature. We have also shown that in the organic molecular semiconductor napthalene (and in related systems) the low-frequency inter-molecular vibrations control the carrier mobility; with 36 atoms in the unit cell, to date this is the record largest first-principles calculation of e-ph interactions and charge transport, made possible by the efficiency of the PERTURBO code. 

A figure highlighting some of the unique capabilities of PERTURBO is attached, showing the accuracy of PERTURBO for calculations on materials with spin-orbit coupling (SOC) and large unit cells, and its favorable performance scaling up 1000s of CPU cores, which enables uniquely challenging calculations on real materials. Taken together, the PERTURBO software package provides a unified platform for investigating electron dynamics in novel families of materials of technological interest. These investigations provide the fundamental understanding for advances in electronics, optoelectronics, energy, computing, quantum technologies, and ultrafast spectroscopy.
